column1: Sunnybank Hills is an outer southern suburb in the City of Brisbane
column4: Sunnybank Hills had a population of 18

column1: == Geography ==
Sunnybank Hills is  about 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) from Brisbane CBD
column3: Australia. It is a large suburb
column4: and adjoins the suburbs of Calamvale

column1: == History ==
Sunnybank Hills was originally part of a much larger area known as Coopers Plains. In 1885
column2: the railway line was extended from Yeerongpilly
column3: and names had to be given to the railway stations built along the line. One of the stations was named after a local farm
column6: 100 m2) of land were taken over for the railway. Brae is the Scottish word for the English word bank
column7: so the area was given boundaries and named Sunnybank. The area of Sunnybank Hills was officially defined in 1971
column8: although it had been unofficially called this for many years.

column1: Autism Therapy & Education Centre opened on 23 July 1977.Sunnybank Hills State School No 1889 opened on 30 January 1979.The Sunnybank Hills Public Library opened in 1987 with a major refurbishment in 2009.In the 2011 census
column2: Sunnybank Hills had a population of 16
column4: Sunnybank Hills had a population of 18

column1: == Geography ==
Sunnybank Hills has numerous ridges and hills
column2: with lower wetter areas in the north and east. These form the marshes near Sunnybank and Runcorn railway stations.[1] There are many parks and greenspaces in the area. The soil is fertile and watered by numerous small creeks
column3: including a large one that flows north–south across the suburb
column4: and the suburb borders on the small wildfowl habitat and wetlands of neighbouring Calamvale Creek.

column1: == Amenities ==

The Brisbane City Council operates a public library in Sunnybank Hills in the Sunnybank Hills Shopping Centre at the corner of Compton and Calam Roads.Churches in Sunnybank Hills include the Southside International Church on the corner of Pinelands and Beenleigh Roads
column2: and Sunnybank Hills Uniting Church on the corner of Hellawell Road and Hillcrest Street.

column1: The suburb is serviced by several shopping centres. These include Shauna Downs on the corner of Wynne Street and Beenleigh Road
column3: and the large Sunnybank Hills Shoppingtown on the corner of Compton & Calam Roads. Sunnybank Hills Shoppingtown features a Woolworths supermarket

column1: Approximately 25% (ABS 2006 Census) of the population is Asian born
column2: and the cultural scene is brought to life with many Asian restaurants
column3: along with numerous coffee shops and eateries of many cultures. Restaurants in Sunnybank Hills and neighbouring Sunnybank include Thai

column1: == Education ==
Sunnybank Hills State School is a government primary (Prep-6) school for boys and girls at 77 Symons Road (27.5952°S 153.0562°E﻿ / -27.5952; 153.0562﻿ (Sunnybank Hills State School)). In 2018
column2: the school had an enrolment of 1376 students with 94 teachers (84 full-time equivalent) and 59 non-teaching staff (38 full-time equivalent). It includes a special education program.Autism Queensland Education & Therapy Centre is a private primary and secondary (Prep-12) school for boys and girls at 437 Hellawell Road (27.5974°S 153.0431°E﻿ / -27.5974; 153.0431﻿ (Autism Queensland Education & Therapy Centre)). In 2018
column3: the school had an enrolment of 144 students with 24 teachers (18 full-time equivalent) and 85 non-teaching staff (37 full-time equivalent).There is no government secondary school in Sunnybank Hills. The nearest government secondary school is Sunnybank State High School in neighbouring Sunnybank to the north.

column1: == Transport ==
Many bus stops with buses running directly to the city every couple of minutes during peak times (does not require transfer). The suburb is also serviced by the train stations
column3: which provide services to the Brisbane CBD and Beenleigh lines.

column1: == Demographics ==
In the 2011 census
column2: Sunnybank Hills recorded a population of 16
column3: 830 people: 50.4% female and 49.6% male.The median age of the Sunnybank Hills population was 34 years
column4: 3 years below the Australian median. Children aged under 15 years made up 16.3% of the population and people aged 65 years and over made up 12.4% of the population.

column1: Sunnybank Hills is a very multicultural suburb. 46.7% of people living in Sunnybank Hills were born in Australia
column2: compared to the national average of 69.8%; the next most common countries of birth were China 10.5%
column6: England 2.2%. Just under half (49.7%) of people spoke only English at home; the next most popular languages were 17.8% Mandarin
column11: Sunnybank Hills includes the largest communities of both Chinese Australians (5
column12: 647 people; 25.4%) and Serbian Australians (178 people; 1.0%) of any suburb in Queensland.Almost half (47%) of the family households in the suburb were couples with children
column15: and 3% are classified as "other family". The great majority (85%) of the dwellings in the suburb are stand-alone houses; townhouses account for another 12%. The houses are mainly modern brick and tile houses but there is a sprinkling of post-war weatherboard homes in the area.The most common religious affiliation was "No Religion" (24.3%); the next most common responses were Catholic 20.1%
